Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 07:20PM DaylilyFan wrote: First, thank you, Kira, for the detailed info. Second, my rad onc ordered 16 treatments to the left breast and 5 "boost" treatments to the tumor site, for a total of 21.  There should be no difference in any side effects.  He said that women with larger breasts (I was a 34/C) are not eligible for the shorter course but I have forgotten the reason.  He also said that the dose is adjusted to be biologically equivalent to the longer course of treatment.  I chose the shorter course because I want to get this over with!   Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: 3wk plus boost vs. 6 wk radiation? arbella arbella

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 08:06AM DaylilyFan wrote: Bear in mind that if you need radiation, it means driving there and back M-F for 4 to 6 weeks.  You can receive rad treatments at many local hospitals, but I stayed put because it wasn't that much farther and I was more comfortable having all my docs (both people and records!) in the same system.  All the best, and I agree that you will feel better once you have a plan of attack!
Posts.Title: Waiting for core biopsy results and scared nancyjg nicole1

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 07:56AM - edited Feb 18, 2010 08:00AM by DaylilyFan Nancy, when the radiologist phoned our house just 2 or 3 days after the core biopsy, I was out and my DH didn't tell me he called!  Fortunately, the doc called back later when I was at home to pick up the phone.  (I can laugh about this now, but I was really steamed at the time....)  This was about 9 pm!  Whenever a doctor calls outside regular business hours, it's not good news, so I wasn't surprised to hear it was invasive cancer (and that invasive meant the cancer wasn't contained by a membrane if I remember correctly) and that a nurse would contact me about scheduling an appointment with a surgeon.  He said further testing would take a couple of weeks (These tests turned out to be the ER, PR, HER-2 stuff.  I learned those results and the tumor size when I met with the surgeon.)  I asked if surgery was time-sensitive and he said no, so we went on vacation the next week and met the surgeon about a week after that.   The tumor grade and stage wasn't determined until after the surgery pathology results came back.  I had been getting my screening mammos done at a major cancer center for 20 years just in case something turned up because my mother and aunt had BC, and the coordination among the various departments is excellent.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Waiting for core biopsy results and scared nancyjg nicole1

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 05:48PM DaylilyFan wrote: My surgeon's nurse told me the swelling was "very normal," but this was her response to everything!  However, my rad onc told me that when he saw it on the scans done to set up my radiation treatment, he was fairly sure it was just fluid.  I would say the lump is now about 1/3 its original size, and I've been doing lots of exercise.  Some women massage it gently, but I just ignore it.  It seems each woman's body is different in the time needed to clear this up.
Posts.Title: swell under arm help icey DaylilyFan

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 02:07AM DaylilyFan wrote: I would talk this out with my gynecologist and ask him/her for "third opinion" suggestions.
Posts.Title: Disagreeing Doctors - Anyone with similar experience? pageroo dlb823

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2009 11:08PM DaylilyFan wrote: My surgery was 9 days ago, and my surgeon put me into a "surgical bra" that is more like a corset, cut very high under the arms, with velcro front closure and strap closures.  It is very supportive but miserably uncomfortable.  I did stick it out for 5 days.  I have tried a Champion step in/pull on sports bra, Spanx racer-back, Amoena's "Hannah" bra, and an old underwire heavy cotton sports bra.  All have their flaws, but switching among them helps.  My incision is closer to the armpit than to the nipple, so it's hard to find a bra that doesn't hit it.  Both the Champion and the Spanx have tight stitching along the edges that digs in.  The Softee line is supposed to be very comfortable but I'm worried about adequate support because the incision does pull if I go without a bra very long.  I asked my surgeon how long the swelling would last, and he said weeks to months--that the healing process is different for everyone but that I would eventually be able to do everything I did before surgery.  The exercises on the American Cancer website have helped with the stabbing/burning nerve pain (neither Percoset nor Flexeril made any difference), and I am going to try a "Yoga for Cancer" class next week.  My sensitive skin is not used to a bra 24/7, and I have a lot of chafing and itching, so I am trying Eucerin Calming lotion.  I am trying to look on the bright side--it could have been so much worse!
Posts.Title: pain after sentinel lymphnode biopsy mimi1964 Kushie

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 06:02PM DaylilyFan wrote: About 10 days after my surgery I noticed a hard lump about the width of a quarter at the bottom of my armpit.  It might have been there from day 1 but was too tender and sore to touch before now.  My surgeon's nurse told me it was probably back tissue and not breast tissue, trying to reassure me that it wasn't cancer.  But back tissue?!  That sounds really weird to me, but I think it might be the default term for not chest/breast.  I've been gently massaging it with no apparent result figuring it can't do any harm. What worries me more is that I can see two stringy things (tendons?) pop up between my upper arm and my armpit when I raise my arm sideways above parallel to the floor.  They are invisible on the non-surgery arm and appeared about a week after I started my Amer. Cancer Soc. stretching exercises.  It also hurts and I'm worried about making things worse, so I am going to email my nurse again.   On the other hand, I know I am very lucky compared to so many other women!  Best to you all...
Posts.Title: My arm still hurts kaeyreed sbmolee

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2010 12:41PM DaylilyFan wrote: Here's my two cents on soy and diets: The pharmacist at my cancer clinic talked to me when I started tamoxifen, and he was only concerned with people who have been in the habit of eating a fair amount of soy regularly.  (For example, some vegetarians depend on soy for protein, and some women for various reasons put soy in their smoothies.  However, this was in the context of drug/food interactions, not BC risk factors in general. My trigger foods, especially when stressed, are bread/crackers/chips and desserts.  If I don't eat them, I lose weight.  If I do, I gain weight.  To maintain my weight, I allow one day a week to eat whatever the heck I want, and that seems to work.  I needed the support of Weight Watchers, though.  I could never have managed by myself!  So go for it, ladies, and keep posting and encouraging each other.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: DaylilyFan wrote: Since many people dislike getting injections, I wanted to point out that coughing seems to help reduce the pain.  In the Science section of the New York Times, Tuesday, January 26, 2010, is a little article about "the cough trick."  You cough moderately before the shot and again during the shot.  (I wouldn't try this without warning your practitioner!)  The article cites a report in BMJ and in Pediatrics journals. Dx 10/5/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Afraid of Shots? DaylilyFan DaylilyFan

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2010 10:36AM DaylilyFan wrote: Mimi, Weight Watchers was a big help to me last year--before BC!   Then when I wanted to be in the best shape possible for surgery, I exercised more and cut back on the breads & desserts.  I think the exercise helped during rads as well because I didn't have the fatigue so many women experience.  Like you, I'm on a low dose of generic Synthroid and my thyroid levels are checked annually.   When I met the med onc before rads, she said tamoxifen was more likely than AIs for me.  The next appt. is in two weeks, so I'll find out soon.  From what I've read, water retention can be an issue, so it's probably a good idea to control the salt in your diet.  Also, remember some women lose weight on hormone therapy, so don't panic!  Good luck!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 10:17AM DaylilyFan wrote: It is indeed a personal decision.  I chose lumpectomy because I did not want to have two surgeries (mastectomy followed by reconstruction) because I want the fewest hours in the hospital possible, especially overnight stays.  Also the need for a plastic surgeon to be involved in the first op would have delayed that more than I cared to wait.  Radiation for me wasn't bad at all, and I was very well cared for.  There is a decision tree on a cancer site somewhere, probably the Susan Komen or the Amer. Cancer Society.  I wish you all the best!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy VS Lumpectomy yunlee72 PiscesMoon

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 04:46AM DaylilyFan wrote: I was diagnosed Oct. 5 (biopsy results after Sept. 4 screening mammogram and followup ultrasound), met with my surgeon Oct. 20, and had the surgery Nov. 19.  "Everyone is different" is my surgeon's mantra!  I was on pins and needles between diagnosis and the first meeting with the surgeon, even though the radiologist who phoned with the diagnosis reassured me.  Then I was much less stressed because I had a plan of action.  It helped that I was treated at a major cancer center, I think, because the scheduling between the different departments was very well co-ordinated.
Posts.Title: How long did you wait for a surgery after you have found a lump? zoegr Raili
